The bill makes a minor consequential amendment to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, to ensure people will be able to use or develop land in Jabiru that is subleased to them by the head lessee.

I want to acknowledge the leadership of the Mirarr traditional owners. Theirs has been a decades-long struggle to secure the recognition and opportunity to forge a future guided by their own aspirations.

In February last year, the parliament passed amendments scheduling four parcels of land as Aboriginal land in the Kakadu National Park surrounding Jabiru. Negotiations are now underway with the traditional owners of Kakadu to secure a leaseback arrangement with the Director of National Parks.

These amendments complement those by giving effect to a leasing arrangement for the traditional owners of Jabiru. Traditional owners right across Kakadu National Park will be in control of the decisions that impact on them and their families for generations to come.

The Prime Minister reflected in his 2020 Closing the Gap address that to rob a person of their right to take responsibility is to deny them their liberty. He made it clear that we must 'restore the right to take responsibility, the right to make decisions and the right to step up. It must be accompanied by a willingness to push decisions down to the people who are closest to them.'

We are embracing this change and I am confident that the Mirarr people will now finally be able to achieve their social, cultural and economic independence. They will be a beacon for others. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Supporting the Wellbeing of Veterans and Their Families) Bill 2020

p.span: Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Supporting the Wellbeing of Veterans and Their Families) Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Chester.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr CHESTER (Gippsland—Deputy Leader of the House, Minister for Defence Personnel and Minister for Veterans' Affairs) (11:15): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Today I present to the House legislation that is designed to improve the wellbeing of veterans and their families.

The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Supporting the Wellbeing of Veterans and Their Families) Bill 2020 addresses three key elements. It implements the government's commitment to create a Veteran Family Advocate, announced by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence, me and the member for Herbert, Phil Thompson, on 5 February this year; it provides changes to better support the transition from ADF service to civilian employment; and, finally, it ensures all recipients of the gold card are treated equally in terms of their benefits.
Earlier this year, the government announced two key roles—the National Commissioner for Defence and Veteran Suicide Prevention, which will be complemented by the Veteran Family Advocate.

The government intends to bring forward legislation to establish the national commissioner later this year, while the wellbeing bill will establish the Veteran Family Advocate as a new commissioner to work as part of the Repatriation Commission and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission.
These commissions are responsible for supporting the administration of veterans' legislation and providing advice to the minister and government in relation to these acts.

The Veteran Family Advocate will work with veterans' families to build our understanding of risk and protective factors relating to the wellbeing of veterans and their families, particularly during their transition from the Australian Defence Force.

They will be responsible for directly engaging with the families of veterans, to help shape policy, improve the design of all veteran programs and services, including mental health support and services.
In addition to performing the statutory function of representing the perspectives of veterans' families within the commissions, they will:
consult with the families of veterans to hear their insights and experience about how we can ease the burden facing veterans' families in supporting their loved one,
work with ex-service organisations which represent families of veterans across Australia, and
participate in key bodies such as the Council for Women and Families United by Defence Service, and the Female Veterans and Veterans' Families Policy Forum.
The Veteran Family Advocate will support the Department of Veterans' Affairs in implementing the government's commitment to enhance the health and wellbeing of the veteran community.
They will do this by ensuring that every part of our veteran support system is focused on veterans' mental health and suicide prevention.
Only families can understand how a veteran feels at a particular moment and the nature of the particular problems their loved ones face.
The government cannot solve the complex problems faced by veterans without the assistance of their families.
It is the start of a partnership between these commissions and the families of veterans.
We all want to support veterans to the best of our ability, whether we are family or government.
By working together we believe we can achieve better results for our veterans.
Schedule 2 of the bill facilitates flexibility in the way programs can be designed to assist the transition from the ADF to the civilian workforce.
This will allow for the establishment of new programs, such as the Support for Employment Program through the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Regulations 2020.
The regulations will contain the details of the employment assistance or benefits, as well as who they will be provided to and in what circumstances they can be provided.
Once established through the regulations, this program will provide eligible veterans with both pre- and post-employment assistance.
This includes career advice, coaching, assistance with skills translation, resume and interview preparation, and coaching to adapt to the structure and styles of communication in civilian employment.
This will ensure similar employment support is available to recently transitioned veterans as is currently available to transitioning Australian Defence Force members.
Schedule 3 of this bill rectifies an unintended omission that has meant that the energy supplement has not been payable to some gold card holders because they are covered under different legislation.

It extends the provision of the energy supplement to Australian participants in the British nuclear tests and British Commonwealth Occupation Force and Australian residents who worked as part of Australian surgical medical teams in Vietnam, ensuring that all gold card holders are treated consistently.
Our veterans were prepared to make great sacrifices when we needed them. As the Australian Defence Veterans' Covenant states: 'For what they have done, this we will do.'
This bill supports the wellbeing of veterans, their families and the wider veteran community.
I commend the bill to the House.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Treasury Laws Amendment (More Flexible Superannuation) Bill 2020

p.span: Treasury Laws Amendment (More Flexible Superannuation) Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Sukkar.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing ) (11:21): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Treasury Laws Amendment (More Flexible Superannuation) Bill 2020 delivers on the Morrison government's election promise to give Australians greater flexibility to contribute to their superannuation as they approach retirement.
This government recognises the realities of the modern Australian workplace—a workplace that has become more flexible than ever before.

Far more Australians are taking career breaks or working part time to raise children; and in particular, we are seeing an unprecedented number of women rejoining the workforce. Many people are choosing to work longer, often part time—choosing to maintain a connection to their professional lives.
And as our workplaces evolve, so too must plans for retirement.
With this great progress comes an imperative for government. We must ensure our super system is equipped with the same flexibility as our workplaces.

The superannuation bring-forward arrangement already provides flexibility in the superannuation system to allow individuals to make up to three years worth of non-concessional contributions to their superannuation in a single year.

This bill therefore amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to extend access to the superannuation bring-forward arrangements to people aged 65 and 66 from 1 July 2020 to better reflect the changing nature of work.

Through this measure, the Morrison government is helping older Australians to boost their retirement savings, especially if they have returned to the workforce, by giving them greater flexibility to make superannuation contributions as they enter retirement.
It also aligns the cut-off age of 67 for the bring-forward arrangements with the eligibility age for the pension, which is scheduled to reach 67 on 1 July 2023.
The measure is part of a broader package announced in the 2019-20 budget context. The remaining measures will:
allow people aged 65 and 66 to make both voluntary concessional and non-concessional contributions without meeting the work test; and
allow those aged 70 to 74 to receive spouse contributions.
The government will give effect to these remaining measures by amending the relevant regulations. Full details of the measures are contained in the EM.

By fulfilling our election commitment through this bill, the Morrison government is continuing to ensure all Australians have additional flexibility in how they save as they transition to retirement. I therefore commend the bill to the chamber.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Treasury Laws Amendment (2020 Measures No. 2) Bill 2020

p.span: Treasury Laws Amendment (2020 Measures No. 2) Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by MrSukkar.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing ) (11:24): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

This omnibus bill, the Treasury Laws Amendment (2020 Measures No. 2) Bill 2020, includes a series of tax measures, including a measure to amend the hybrid mismatch rules, continuing the Morrison government's work on combating multinational tax avoidance while ensuring that compliance burdens are kept to a minimum. The bill also allows employers to report information already required for child support under Single Touch Payroll, further streamlining employer reporting obligations. The bill establishes a deductible gift recipient general category for men's sheds and women's sheds and includes a number of other organisations on the list of deductible gift recipients. The bill also includes a measure providing funding for Australia's continued financial support of the World Bank. Finally, this bill will also allow the ATO to share critical JobKeeper related information with the Fair Work Commission and the Fair Work Ombudsman to ensure employers comply with the scheme.

In more detail, schedule 1 amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997, continuing again the government's commitment to tackling multinational tax avoidance by improving Australia's hybrid mismatch rules, which are based on one of 15 actions from the OECD/G20 Base Erosion and Profit Shifting Project.

The hybrid mismatch rules are designed to prevent multinational companies from exploiting differences in the tax treatment of instruments or entities between jurisdictions which enable those companies to defer or reduce tax.

The amendments in this bill will ensure that the hybrid mismatch rules operate as intended and help to ensure the integrity of Australia's income tax laws and their application to multinational enterprises. The amendments achieve this by making technical changes to the rules which clarify their operation and prevent the rules from applying in inappropriate circumstances.

Schedule 2 of the bill amends the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to broaden the information employers can voluntarily report under the Single Touch Payroll rules to include employer withholding of child support deductions and child support garnishee amounts. This measure will further streamline employer reporting to government, demonstrating the efficiency gains for employers that are provided by Single Touch Payroll.

Schedule 3 of the bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to establish a deductible gift recipient general category for men's sheds and women's sheds. This will enable sheds to more easily access DGR status from 1 July 2020, which in turn helps them attract public financial support for their very important activities. The Morrison government fully supports the important work undertaken by men's sheds and women's sheds, and this is a demonstration of that.

Donors to DGR endorsed sheds can claim, once these amendments are made, an income tax deduction for donations of $2 or more. The DGR tax arrangements are intended to encourage philanthropy and provide additional support for the not-for-profit sector.

There are currently over 1,000 men's sheds and around 20 women's sheds. The number of sheds is growing, as the movement gains support around the country for the benefits that it provides our community.
Eligibility for endorsement in this new DGR category requires sheds to demonstrate that their activities advance mental health and prevent or relieve social isolation.

Schedule 4 of the bill amends the International Finance Corporation Act 1955 and International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 to effect obligations that the World Bank's International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Finance Corporation have under this bill. Both of these play a vital role in providing financial assistance and advisory services to middle- and low-income developing countries.

This assistance creates significant benefits throughout our Indo-Pacific region, allowing countries to reduce poverty and build shared prosperity through investment in much-needed physical infrastructure and improved social outcomes.
The IBRD and IFC periodically raise capital to fund their activities by issuing new shares to member countries, including Australia.

However, our participation in these capital raisings is a costly and time-consuming process, requiring the drafting and introduction of new legislation for each instance where Australia subscribes to an IBRD or IFC capital increase.

These amendments therefore will streamline the process by creating a clear legislative framework for Australia to enter into agreements, or amend existing agreements, to subscribe to any capital increases. The amendments also establish standing special appropriations that will facilitate payments that Australia has committed to in subscribing to capital increases.

As these types of purchases of shares in the World Bank Group constitute a formal international treaty action, they will always be subject to oversight and consideration by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.
The passage of these amendments will also enable Australia to make its $154 million contribution to the IBRD's latest capital raising that was announced in October 2018.

Schedule 5 to the bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to include C.E.W. Bean Foundation, Governor Phillip International Scholarship Trust, High Resolves, Australian Academy of Law, Foundation Broken Hill, Motherless Daughters, Superannuation Consumers' Centre and The Headstone Project (Tasmania) on the list of DGRs. This will allow members of the public to receive income tax deductions for the donations they make to these eight organisations.

Finally, schedule 6 to the bill allows the Australian Taxation Office to share JobKeeper related information with the Fair Work Commission and the Fair Work Ombudsman. Access to this information will help the Fair Work Commission and Fair Work Ombudsman address JobKeeper related compliance issues, in relation to obligations under the Fair Work Act 2009. This measure, of course, will help the JobKeeper scheme operate efficiently and equitably.
Full details of these measures are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Amendment (APRA Industry Funding) Bill 2020

p.span: Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Amendment (APRA Industry Funding) Bill 2020
First Reading

Bill and explanatory memorandum to this bill, and to the Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020, Authorised Non-operating Holding Companies Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020, General Insurance Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020, Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020, Retirement Savings Account Providers Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020 and the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020, presented by Mr Sukkar.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing ) (11:32): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Amendment (APRA Industry Funding) Bill 2020, along with the APRA levy imposition bills being introduced alongside it, will ensure the government's cost recovery arrangements for APRA continue to operate effectively. These bills will do this by ensuring the Treasurer has adequate flexibility to set the levies at a level required for institutions to pay their required share and by ensuring the Commonwealth can continue to collect relevant costs for its regulatory activities in the financial sector. Both of these changes, of course, reflect the evolving environment we find ourselves in.
In introducing this bill today, we are delivering on a commitment made to review the methodology of APRA levies and address legislative barriers to their effective operation.

Since 1998, when the APRA Act and the levy imposition acts set the current levy arrangements, the role of APRA has obviously expanded and increased. Additionally, other agencies have taken on a role in regulating the financial sector, the cost of which should be borne by those institutions that bring about the need for that regulation.
Legislation is currently preventing the largest banks from paying the appropriate share of the cost of APRA's regulation.
The APRA industry funding bill and the levy imposition bills will fix these issues.
Schedule 1 of the bill expands the conditions under which levy money is payable to the Commonwealth in respect of regulation of prudentially regulated entities to also include consumer outcomes.

The levy imposition bills increase the statutory cap on levy collections for APRA's direct supervisory work on institutions from $1½ million, as set in 2005, to $10 million, subject to indexation which uses the latest available CPI data.

These bills will ensure there are no regulatory barriers to all institutions paying their appropriate share and to bearing the costs of regulatory activities undertaken by the Commonwealth agencies in relation to APRA regulated entities, which aim to promote consumer outcomes.
In closing, these bills will ensure the framework of the APRA levies keeps pace with the evolving regulatory environment and the size of the industry.
Full details of the measures are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020

p.span: Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill presented by Mr Sukkar.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr SUKKAR (Deakin—Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing ) (11:35): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020 complements the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority Amendment (APRA Industry Funding) Bill 2020 by ensuring the Treasurer has adequate flexibility to set the levies at a level required for authorised deposit-taking institutions to pay their appropriate amount.
Full details of the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
Debate adjourned.

p.span: Superannuation Supervisory Levy Imposition Amendment Bill 2020

Norfolk Island Amendment (Supreme Court) Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill presented by Mrs Marino.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mrs MARINO (Forrest—Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories) (11:42): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
The Norfolk Island Amendment (Supreme Court) Bill 2020 makes technical amendments to provisions of the Norfolk Island Act 1979 dealing with the Supreme Court of Norfolk Island.

Amendments made to the act in 2018 authorised the Supreme Court to sit on the Australian mainland in the exercise of its civil and criminal jurisdiction. These amendments allowed for a matter to be heard and a jury to be empanelled in another state or territory. The measures were modelled on similar amendments made for Christmas Island in 1987 and were intended to ensure trials can be conducted fairly, improving community confidence in the Norfolk Island justice system.

The amendments in the bill address some technical issues with respect to these provisions regulating off-island sittings of the Supreme Court and also clarify the basis under which travelling allowances are determined for its judges.
These amendments will enhance the effective administration of the Norfolk Island justice system.
I commend the bill to the House.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Aged Care Legislation Amendment (Emergency Leave) Bill 2020

p.span: Aged Care Legislation Amendment (Emergency Leave) Bill 2020
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Wyatt, for Mr Hunt.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr WYATT (Hasluck—Minister for Indigenous Australians) (11:44): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Today I'm introducing the Aged Care Legislation Amendment (Emergency Leave) Bill 2020.

This bill amends the Aged Care Act 1997 and the Aged Care (Transitional Provisions) Act 1997 to introduce a new type of leave which can be utilised by permanent residents of aged-care homes in particular emergency situations.

The Australian government is committed to ensuring that all older Australians have access to high-quality aged-care services whilst ensuring that they are treated with respect and dignity. Integral to this is the empowering of aged-care residents to make their own decisions about their emotional wellbeing and physical health and safety.

This is particularly relevant in emergency situations, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. If a resident, or their family, is concerned that the current health emergency is impacting on the safe provision of residential aged care, they have the right to choose to take leave from the aged-care home without incurring financial burden and without the fear of losing their room.

In the current environment, permanent residents of an aged-care home are entitled to take up to 52 days per year of what is known as social leave. When a resident exceeds their 52 days of social leave, the aged-care provider no longer receives a subsidy payment for that resident. Therefore, in order to retain their place within the aged-care home, the aged-care provider charges a fee to the resident.

The current COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the inadequacy of these leave provisions. Many permanent aged-care residents are seeking to temporarily relocate to stay with family and reduce their risk of exposure to the virus. For these residents, the only options available are to use their social leave allocation or remain in the aged-care home.

The difficulty is that many residents will exceed their social leave before they are ready to return to the aged-care home. If they choose to remain on leave, the additional charges that may be incurred to secure their room place a significant and unnecessary financial burden on families, carers and residents. In many cases, residents may simply not be able to afford the additional charges and therefore cannot take the leave they desire.

The government has received a large number of representations about this issue. The isolation, lack of visitation and inability to stay with family for the duration of the current COVID-19 pandemic has caused great anxiety for a significant number of aged-care residents and their families. Many residents, and their families, are fearful of the risk of contracting or spreading the virus whilst in an aged-care home.

The amendments in this bill introduce a new emergency leave type for permanent aged-care residents, which will be activated during pandemics, natural disasters and other large-scale emergency situations as determined by the government.

This new leave type will not be available on a regular basis. Once activated, the emergency leave will only be available for a set period, as determined by the government, and will be applied either nationally or to a specific area or service. This will ensure the flexibility needed to allow government to address situations such as floods, bushfire emergencies or future instances of isolated or regional outbreaks of COVID-19.

In light of the current emergency, provision is being made to apply these changes retrospectively to 1 April 2020. This will ensure that residents who have already been financially impacted by the need to take leave from their aged-care home will be adequately covered. It will also ensure providers are not financially disadvantaged.

This bill ensures that permanent aged-care residents and their families are supported to make decisions about personal safety in emergency situations, and not suffer unnecessary financial burden as a result. It also ensures that, following an emergency, residents are still able to use their social leave entitlement to maintain their normal visiting and special events routine with their families and friends, which is important for emotional and mental health.
This change is in the best interests of all older Australians and the broader community by supporting a resident's right to make their own decisions about their care.
I commend the bill to the House.
Debate adjourned.
Leave granted for second reading debate to resume at a later hour this day.
TARIFF PROPOSALS
Customs Tariff Proposal (No. 1) 2020
Mr WOOD (La Trobe—Assistant Minister for Customs, Community Safety and Multicultural Affairs) (11:49): I move:
Customs Tariff Proposal (No. 1) 2020.

The Australian government is committed to ensuring that our community has access to medical and hygiene equipment needed to treat, diagnose and prevent the spread of coronavirus. The Customs Tariff Proposal (No. 1) 2020 that I've just tabled inserts a new concessional item into schedule 4 of the Customs Tariff Act 1995. This new concessional item, No. 57, provides a free rate of customs duty for eligible medical and hygiene products needed to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Item 57 has a retrospective commencement. It applies to imported goods for which the time for working out the rate of duties is between 1 February 2020 and 31 July 2020. Item 57 applies to goods prescribed by the by-law. The new by-law prescribes goods including critical equipment such as masks, gloves, face shields, gowns, goggles, test kits, certain disinfectants and soap.

Item 57 applies to the eligible prescribed goods regardless of their origin. This means importers who previously needed to prove origin under one of our free trade agreements can now access the same free rate of duty without the compliance costs associated with claiming preferential tariff treatment. This will temporarily simplify the import process and ensure these vital goods get to where they are needed most. These goods are essential to safeguard our healthcare professionals and essential workers, and we thank them for the magnificent work they are doing right across Australia. They also are required as we begin to relax the restrictions the government has applied to combat the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.

This customs tariff proposal is a targeted and proportionate measure to support Australia's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Other countries have taken similar steps to temporarily remove or reduce custom duties on medical and hygiene products to support the availability of these goods. By introducing this measure, the government is helping to ensure that Australia can secure supplies of these essential goods for our community.

Just in conclusion, I thank all the Australian Border Force staff for the incredible and amazing work they're doing, and Commissioner Mike Outram for leading this magnificent team of people who have just done an incredible job of protecting Australians.
Debate adjourned.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (11:53): On behalf of the member for Flynn I present report No. 12 of the Standing Committee on Petitions.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP Ms Lisa Chesters MP Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

span.span: Report relating to the consideration of petitions and matters relating to the petitions system

p.span: The committee met in private session on 25 March.
1. The committee resolved to present the following petitions in accordance with standing order 207:
From 1 petitioner - requesting a ban for travel to and from Korea during COVID-19 (EN1359)
From 58 petitioners - requesting safe houses and support for victims of domestic violence (EN1360)
From 1 petitioner - requesting for the sale of nicotine based vaping products to be legalised (EN1362)
From 1 petitioner - requesting a trial of two new road safety strategies
From 3 petitioners - requesting for a right to repair on goods purchased
From 1 petitioner – requesting support for the Brimbank Girls and Women in Sport 2020 Agenda (EN1368)
From 5 petitioners - requesting an increase for the single aged pension
From 2 petitioners - requesting a change to the manufacturing of certain vehicle parts (EN1374)
From 2 petitioners - requesting that schools and universities be shut down during COVID-19 (EN1375)
From 1 petitioner - requesting the removal of GST on accredited exercise physiologists (EN1376)
From 14 petitioners - requesting a ban on all single use plastic items
From 1,341 petitioners - requesting that the processing time for 887 visas be shortened (EN1378)
From 2 petitioners – requesting a change to taxation (EN1380)
From 4 petitioners - requesting a tax deduction or subsidy for electric vehicles
From 8 petitioners - requesting changes to the cashless welfare card scheme
From 1 petitioner - requesting the closure of Australia's borders and a ban on large crowds during COVID-19 (EN1384)
From 2 petitioners - requesting the closure of Australia's borders during COVID-19 (EN1385)
From 5 petitioners – requesting a temporary ban on international flights
From 17 petitioners - requesting financial relief for the events industry during COVID-19 (EN1387)
From 5 petitioners - requesting that schools and universities be closed during the COVID-19 (EN1388)
From 2 petitioners - requesting for the House to state support for the use of face masks to minimise the spread of COVID-19 (EN1389)
From 11 petitioners – requesting for the COVID-19 stimulus package to also benefit live entertainers (EN1391)
From 1 petitioner - requesting that AFL season be postponed due to COVID-19
From 1 petitioner - requesting that schools and universities be closed temporarily during COVID-19 (EN1395)
From 2 petitioners - requesting that all non-essential work, travel and education be shutdown to contain COVID-19 (EN1396)
From 2 petitioners - requesting a mandate to quarantine all international arrivals (EN1398)

Mr Ken O'Dowd
Chair—Petitions Committee
PETITIONS
Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (11:53): by leave—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, and in accordance with standing order 207, I present the following petitions:
COVID-19: Korea
Novel Coronavirus from Korea

The outbreak of the novel Coronavirus in Korea is very serious and the speed of spread is much quicker that expected. Although the Korea is said to try their best to prevent the spread, little effect has been seen. The number of newly diagnosed of the Coronavirus jump significantly daily. I am very concerned that people in our community, especially those vulnerable people such as children and elderly, will be exposed to the virus from people travelling from and through Korea.
We therefore ask the House to issue a travel ban or at lest compulsory quarantine requirements to people who travel from or through Korea in the last 14 days.
From 1 citizen (EN1359)
Domestic and Family Violence
Safe Houses and Support for victims of Domestic Violence

In light of recent events in QLD but relevant to the current status of those either affected or currently living in a Domestic violence environment it is clear that families and individuals who are the victims or violence either verbal, physical or otherwise require immediate assistance and refuge from their perpetrators. Too many in our community are held hostage and captive within their homes due to the non availability of suitable refuges, shelters or safe accommodation by which they can live in peace and comfort. We have a moral and ethical obligation to accommodate such victims in these circumstances and meet words with appropriate actions and provide the necessary accommodation, financial & physiological support to these individuals and/or families.

We therefore ask the House to urgently review the current system and seek a complete overhaul of resources in this area. We ask the house to consider the set up a non-political agnostic organisation skilled in this area to implement the changes necessary to adequately deliver a sustainable programme for housing and other support services for those affected by any form of domestic violence. Clearly the current system has failed and an urgent solution needs to be sort and implemented to arrest the number of fatalities and victims of domestic violence.
From 58 citizens (EN1360)
E-Cigarettes
Legalise sale of nicotine based vaping products in Australia

Nicotine based vaping and e-cigarette products cannot be sold in Australia. Greg Hunt is pushing to ban nicotine-based vaping products from being imported into Australia. This discrimination against adults who CHOOSE to vape nicotine products needs to end. I currently purchase my nicotine vaping products from New Zealand where nicotine salts are still legal and the manufacture of nicotine-based vaping products is also legal. I pay overseas tax and bank fees for a product I should be able to buy in Australia, therefore creating jobs for Australians. Smoking cigarettes is only for the super rich because of over-the-top taxation laws. Let us aging ex-smokers have some dignity in our old age and legalize the production and sale of nicotine vaping products in Australia.
We therefore ask the House to vote a resounding NO to Greg Hunt's ban on the importation of nicotine vaping products by Australian citizens.
From 1 citizen (EN1362)
Road Safety
Trial two new ROAD SAFETY STRATEGIES toward ZERO FATALITIES

Between late nineties till around two thousand and seven I studied many vehicle crash videos and came to the realization one in five may not have happened if the stationery vehicle ahead had the brakelights illuminated, designing a system though not realizing the simplicity of circuit till five or six months ago :-

1/ C.L.I.P.S. , [ condenser lineal inertia power switch ], offering three to five minutes of brakelights illumination if required till vehicle moves, with an inclusion to effect same illumination from handbrake engagement, [ though not requiring inertia switch component ], for awareness vehicle IS stationery on level or unlevel road.

2/ C.A.P.S. , [ corner awareness placement sign ], should be installed on every blind and / or crested road corner due to guide posts, though staggered toward apex of corner, seem same distance apart, during late speed reduction. One sign mounted halfway would allow for safer spacial awareness of corner length.
And combined strategies will effect estimated twenty percent less road fatality, less congestion, and less carbon emission.

We therefore ask the House to, though promotions at assessment stage with transport N.S.W., and would be very difficult to amend only state registration/road laws regarding trials, amend A.D.R. 31-4 for C.L.I.P.S., and also necessary amendments allowing roll out of C.A.P.S., plus enaction for funding availability, if applicable
From 1 citizen (EN1366)
Consumer Rights
Right to Repair
Requesting a right to repair legalisation to ensure access to repair information, spare parts for electronics for consumers and independent repair technicians for all products
Manufacturers often restrict the sale of spare parts and access to service bulletins & service manuals to authorised repair technicians and do not offer these to the public.
We therefore ask the House to introduce legalisation for Right to Repair for all products including a mandatory data sharing scheme similar to the one for motor car industry.
Ensure access to spare parts and repair information to the general public and not just to authorised repairers.
From 3 citizens (EN1367)
Women in Sport
Brimbank's Girls and Women in Sport 2020 Agenda

Currently only 4.1% of girls and women are registered to play sport in Brimbank compared to the Melbourne average of 9.3%. While 3,200 women play organised sport in Brimbank, only 22 per cent of Brimbank residents participate in organised sport compared to the Melbourne average of 50 per cent.
To improve local sport and health outcomes, Brimbank is calling for its fair share of funding for girls and women.

This petition asks the House to support Brimbank's Girls and Women in Sport 2020 Agenda, through federal funding for better local sporting facilities at the grass-roots level, to provide more change room, pitch and light facilities for local female sport teams.
Brimbank is also calling for federal investment towards the St Albans Health and Wellbeing Hub and making Brimbank the 'Home of the Matildas' at Sydenham Park.
We therefore ask the House to support the Transforming Brimbank Girls and Women in Sport 2020 Agenda which includes:
A fair North-West City Deal that supports local projects
Funding for St Albans Health and Wellbeing Hub
Making Brimbank the 'Home of the Matildas' at Sydenham Park
Funding to accommodate increased demand for girls' and women's grassroot sport facilities in Brimbank
Investment in the development of a regional multi-sport facility in Brimbank
Developing strategic partnerships to support the Transforming Brimbank – Sport and Recreation Health agenda
Development of an Integrated Transport Strategy for the West, that links with Sunshine Super Hub with the region's Sport and Recreation Precincts
From 1 citizen (EN1368)
Age Pension
Increase Single Aged Pension

The petition of the Australian Pensioners' & Superannuants' League (QLD) Inc and citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the current single aged pension is not enough to cover basic living needs as the current aged couple pension is $1407. As at the 20th of September 2019 when a person is widowed this reduces to $933.40, a reduction when support is most needed. Difference between a coupled and widowed pension is $473.60. This has not been reviewed for a long time and we believe this difference should be 18% between the two pensions, not 33%.
We therefore ask the House to to enact necessary legislation to ensure that the difference between the Aged Couple Pension and the Aged Single Pension is reduced to 18% from 33%.
From 5 citizens (EN1370)
Road Safety
STOP CONTINUING DANGEROUS DESIGN FAULT:- VEHICLES FRONT INDICATOR LENSES.

For a few years now I have noticed more and more new vehicle models being fitted with unfrosted and/or sharp corregation on inside of lens of front indicators. I do not know how they passed design approval as in the sunlight it is almost impossible to know if operational or not unless nearly close enough to touch the vehicle. FROSTED AND/OR SHARP CORREGATED LENSES should only be permitted with minimum one quarter of lens flat at fifteen degree forward sloping angle due to rain/fog reflecting beams. Pedestrians and infirmmed are at greater risk as no protection crossing the road when design faulted vehicle turning into path, [ and operator unaware indicators unnoticeable ]; good looks should not come before safety

We therefore ask the House to Amend A.D.R. 6/00 - Direction indicators including MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS of FROSTED AND/OR HEAVILY SHARP CORREGATION, [ inside of lens ], with a QUARTER OF LENS AREA BEING FLAT and SET FIFTEEN DEGREE FORWARD SLOPE, plus urge relevent manufacturers to deliver frosted covers to owners of vehicles with clear front indicators. plus gazettes to motor industry, of relevance .
From 2 citizens (EN1374)
COVID-19: Schools
Shut school/uni down for an amount of time amidst COVID19
As COVID19 has influenced over 100,000 people around 80 countries, and the reason for how Australian infected is still unclear.
We therefore ask the House to at least consider closing schools/colleges down in the coming weeks or as soon as possible, in addition to taking necessary actions to prevent further spread.
From 2 citizens (EN1375)
Goods and Services Tax
Removal of GST on Accredited Exercise Physiologists
The exercise physiology profession was less than a decade old when GST was brought in and despite services being recognised by Medicare back in 2006, the GST issue was not rectified.
Impacts of GST on Exercise Physiologist –

Financial Burden - Adds 10 per cent charge to each consultation, unlike most other health services. Average cost is $70-$100 for an hour consultation with exercise physiologist (thus an added $7-$10 cost per session for patient)
Medical System - Patients not continuing care further impact the health system, through hospitalisation, surgery and straining other services.
Patient Confusion - Creates confusion for patients given added charges unlike other commonly used services, such as podiatry and physiotherapy.
Business Impact – Many practitioners absorb the charge instead of passing on to patient. The GST also creates significant accountancy costs for businesses.
We therefore ask the House to remove GST on Accredited Exercise Physiology services
From 1 citizen (EN1376)
Environment
Total Ban on ALL single use plastic items

The plastic pollution problem is well documented world wide. Smaller and less developed countries are taking the initiative to change habits and supporting local industries and the local economy by finding products that are not sourced by the boat load from China or India. Plastic shopping bags from retail chains, grocery stores and take aways - Drinking straws and plastic cups, coffee cups and plastic cutlery continue to fill our limited landfill resources, polluting the earth of our children for generations to come. Plastic bags are in our water ways ruining our pristine natural environment, and endangering our all ready struggling native animals.

We therefore ask the House to totally ban all single use plastic items. Removing any and all labelling that identifies any plastic item as re-useable as this has not worked and the number of plastic bags distributed by take away outlets, retail outlets and grocery outlets has not changed. They simply made the bags thicker.
From 14 citizens (EN1377)
Skilled Regional Visas
Visa 887 processing time shortening

We are a group of people who applied for Visa 887 after living for 2 years in regional areas. We have lived for 2 year without Medicare or Centrelink in a regional area where there are not many job offers. Now the processing time for this visa is 19-22 months and this have a great impact on our lives, we can not find jobs because we are on a bridging visa, we can not buy houses because we can not take loans from banks because we are not permanent residents, our kids can not go to universities because we can not get government loans, we can not go overseas because of our current bridging visa, we can not feel stability in our lives. We have contributed to the regional community, we have paid our taxes without any government help. We are skilled immigrants on visa 489. We have met difficulties to live in regional areas for 2 years and find jobs which is hard in regional areas. We need to be treated like other skilled visas such as 190 which the processing time is 8-11 months or visa 491 which is 3 months. The question is why the immigration department is prioritizing offshore skilled applicants over onshore applicants who faced hardships already in regional areas. We are the forgotten visa, we do not get fair chance like other skilled visa applicants
We therefore ask the House to decrease visa 887 processing time to 6-8 months
From 1,341 citizens (EN1378)
Taxation
Stop the donation of $20billion of taxes to individuals

We feel this is a dereliction of duty to donate tax dollars that have been collected on the sweat and sacrifice of every day Australians, which will be thrown away by donating to individuals. This once in a lifetime spend can be used to better the country for all and leave a legacy. Infrastructure, schools, digitisation, green climate change - all examples of a better long term return for the country.

We therefore ask the House to act more intelligently and responsibly with this enormous responsibility of utilising our hard earned tax dollars and invest in strategies that are better thought through and have a ROI for all Australians.
From 2 citizens (EN1380)
Transport Industry
Reduce taxes or subsidise Electric Vehicles to reduce emissions
Electric vehicles are free from harmful emissions and are available for purchase, although are not commonly seen on our roads due to the high cost and lack of available power stations.

We therefore ask the House to create an incentive for Australians to purchase Electric vehicles. This can be done in a number of ways, including reduced import taxes, the removal of luxury car taxes for vehicles that fall over the LCT threshold, and by creating a National subsidy for purchases of the emission free vehicles.

Furthermore, there are currently limited recharging stations for electric vehicles, therefore a further subsidy to boost the installation of charging points throughout major shopping centers and petrol stations throughout Australia.
From 4 citizens (EN1381)
Pensions and Benefits
Cashless Card. Indue Card.

All reciepiants on welfare , whether Newstart, Aged, Carers, SHOULD be asked by Centrelink if these people on welfare would like their benefits to be paid on the Cashless Card or NOT, These people should be made to sign an agreement to have or have not their benefits paid in this way , or to keep the usual method in place. There should be NO contest against if these welfare people choose to or NOT choose this Indue method. Whilst I admit there are some cases that warrant this process, most will NOT agree to this new payment method.

We therefore ask the House toe the Australian people do here ask the Speaker of the House to honour this request and post it on the current agenda of that sitting. I believe that this is warranted due to the amount of negativity upon this action brought about by the current Government.
From 8 citizens (EN1382)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Close Australia's borders and shot down large events, gathering

The Australian people are worried as the coronavirus is spreading fast across the country, from people that have traveled and come from other countries and brining back coronavirus. We need to close down large events and gatherings to holt the spread. People have been stock piling non perishables and toilet paper because they are in panic.
We therefore ask the House to close Australia's boarders and shutdown large event with large crowds.
From 1 citizen (EN1384)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Shut the borders to Australia

We the people of Australia request that the Australian government shut air borders immediately . All flights must be cancelled . Our only hope of slowing the spread of COVID 19 as evidenced by the cases in Italy and South Korea is isolation. Please act now before it's too late. Shut the borders now.
We therefore ask the House to shut Australian borders immediately
From 2 citizens (EN1385)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
To slow coronavirus spread, ban international flights (except freight)

The number of Australian-resident coronavirus cases is doubling every 7 days. This is exponential growth and means there will be thousands of cases within a month on the current trajectory and tens of thousands of cases by May. We know that the sick and elderly are especially vulnerable. Hundreds and even thousands of deaths is not out of the questions.

The fastest, cheapest and most effective means to slow the spread of the virus is to stop the international inflow of people. Do this and less effort is required to do social distancing within the community.

This is not an anti-foreigner request. Every nation must do what is required to slow the spread of this disease and 'flatten the curve' of cases so that the health system can cope. Australia is fortunate to be an island. It would be bizarre not to take advantage of this situation. This approach is favoured by the highly respected Grattan Institute.
We, the signees urgently request our governments, MPS and medical advisers to act promptly.
We therefore ask the House to call an emergency debate and direct the Government to immediately ban international flights, except freight.
From 5 citizens (EN1386)
COVID-19: Economy
Relief Funds for Events Industry

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the health threat of this pandemic is causing the the public to isolate themselves, the $14.7B Australian Events Industry is suffering significant losses of existing business, revenue, cash flow and experiencing major regression.

The forward planning of all events (small, medium and large) has completely stopped due to the uncertainty and lack of confidence in the market. This represents a major disruption and $14.7B negative financial impact on the events industry in Australia.
The media is highly publicising a global shutdown and total restriction of crowds, audiences and spectators attending any events at all, such as Italy which has banned weddings.

The events industry in Australia is now suffering the major consequences of the coronavirus, including short, medium and long term negative financial impacts, incl; lost revenue, increased unemployment and business closures.
There is a very real, long term negative economic impact that the covid-19 pandemic is having on the events industry globally, including Australia.

We therefore ask the House to support the Events Industry and lobby and request the Federal Government to provide immediate financial relief, support and assistance including tax cuts, rebates and funding grants specifically for the events industry, particularly the organisations responsible for management and planning of events, as they represent near $5B of economic contribution, as SME's.

We also ask the House to support the events industry and lobby and the Australian Government to effectively support the events industry through marketing, media, PR and communication support activities.
From 17 citizens (EN1387)
COVID-19: Schools
Close all school and universities before the pandemic worsens
We are at a turning point.

The R0 value of COVID-19 (Wuhan Virus) is estimated to be around 2 to 3.7, which means every 1 confirmed case, on average, infects around 3.7 healthy people. To visualise how high this is, seasonal flu's R0 value is approximately 1.3, while the notorious Spanish Flu had a R0 value around 2 to 3, lower than COVID-19. (Internet values, open to change)

If schools and universities continue to open, the number of infected may rise exponentially, possibly at an uncontrollable rate. The Coronavirus not only transmits via cough, but also aerosol—particles suspended in the air—which means if one could get infected by staying in the same room as a patient while having never seen him/her (check out the SARS deaths at Amoy Garden, Hong Kong).

While the death rate seems to be low (especially in China), we must bear in mind that this is the result of extreme quarantine measures. The country was paralysed—from universities to malls, from restaurants to cinemas, everything was shut, except for pharmacies, hospitals, supermarkets, and some other living necessities.
Do we want to bring a deadly disease to our friends and family?
Preemptive measures are more effective than mending afterwards. We must take action now.
We therefore ask the House to close all school and universities in Australia before the pandemic worsens
From 5 citizens (EN1388)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Wear masks to minimise the spread of COVID-2019

Coronavirus outbreak is becoming more serious across Australia as the number of confirmed cases is rising daily. Some of the recent confirmed cases have been to public places such as the South Melbourne Market and the MCG thus local transmission is expected to be fast and widespread. One infected person can potentially infect 2-4 other people and no one knows who the next confirmed case might be, they might be right next to us or our family on the street coughing or sneezing.

According to the experiment conduct by the Department of Mathematics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, (titled violent expiratory events on coughing and sneezing) which highlighted that sneezing and coughing can spread up to 8m and 6m long respectively in the air and can last up to 10 minutes. Droplets from sneeze/cough are one of the major media that coronavirus spread, wearing a mask is never a sign that you are sick, but it is strong and powerful protection to distance us and our family away from any potential danger.

China used to have the most confirmed case, but this number has soon dropped down and many provinces have no more confirmed case, this rapid decrease is attributed to action from the government that asking people to wear a mask when going out.
We therefore ask the House to suggest the general public wearing masks when going out to the public area in order to protect us away from being infected.
From 2 citizens (EN1389)
COVID-19: Economy
Broaden the federal stimulus package to benefit live entertainers.

Many of us in the creative industries have incomes which depend directly on ticket sales and people coming out to attend live events, something which is directly in conflict with current government and medical advice.

Live events such as Melbourne, Brisbane and Canberra Comedy Festivals and similar festivals in different arts areas have been or are being cancelled, evaporating our incomes completely and instantly. In addition, many of us have already incurred significant expenses such as advertising, airfares and accommodation in anticipation of now cancelled festivals.

Contrary to common belief, the Comedy Festival and festivals like it are not employers of the comedians who perform. Comedians and producers essentially run their own businesses and merely register with and take part in festivals.

As neither employees of any business, apprentices nor business owners, this leaves freelance live performers and those associated with the shows they present uncovered by any of the recently announced government support measures at a time when the nature of the work we do means we will bear the economic brunt of the necessary precautionary measures more directly than most.

We therefore ask the House to expand the reach of the stimulus package to take account of live performers and associated staff whose incomes derive directly from live performances which are rendered impractical under the current circumstances and government advice.
From 11 citizens (EN1391)
COVID-19: Sports
Postpone AFL season
This petition is to postpone the AFL season rather than play it with no crowds.

Why does the AFL think it's ok to jeopardise the wellbeing of players? The threat of COVID-19 is still in early stages in Australia. What if a player contracts the virus and passes it to another team member? (whether at their club or another). The team or teams would then have to be quarantined not allowing them to play for 2 weeks which will cost them dearly for the season. Let's use an example: If the virus passes in 6 weeks and the all clear is given for the AFL to resume matches, every team can play each other once, with finals to resume as normal. If the virus goes for longer than 6 weeks a raffle system can be put in place. If the COVID-19 is still not sorted by 3-4 months then cancel the season indefinitely.

The game will not be the same without a crowd. AFL crowds play a huge factor and for these reasons please sign the Petition if you too would like the AFL to postpone the season for the players, their families and the supporters.
We therefore ask the House to postpone the AFL season until it is safe to play for everyone included rather than start it with no crowds.
From 1 citizen (EN1393)
COVID-19: Schools
Close all Schools and Universities temporarily to prevent COVID-19 spread

We would like the House to implement extreme measures now in regard to school closures revolving COVID- 19 situation. Most classes require students to work in a very close distance with a huge number of students per class, these could surely cause a super-spreading of COVID-19 among the students.
Request:

We therefore ask the House to close all schools temporarily to slow down the process of COVID-19 spread, and prompt all schools to enforce online learning. We, teenagers, can be the worst super-spreaders which could adversely affect the elderly or people at risk.
We hope the House can consider our advice and for school closures.
From 1 citizen (EN1395)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Shutdown all non-essential work, travel and education to contain COVID-19
The pandemic of COVID-19 can be best ameliorated by containment.
Our best chance to save thousands of lives is to #shutitdown

We appreciate the consequences and gravity of doing so but feel that the extensive potential suffering of our citizens and health workers as demonstrated by the experience of other jurisdictions call for urgent, unprecedented action.
Less than three weeks ago (on 23Feb20) Italy had 150 cases. This is exactly where Australia was yesterday. Now they have 12000 cases with over 800 dead. We've only got one shot to make a difference.

If it's not safe to hold gatherings of over 500 people because of the possible rapid spread that could occur, there is a logical inconsistency in non-essential places of work, education and mass transit systems remaining open.
#shutitdown
We therefore ask the House to
* Shut down all non-essential contact between people by maximising all work and learn from home measures.
* Shut down all non-essential travel in and out and around the country by mass transit.
* Work with retailers to ramp up delivery services to homes to reduce human to human contact where possible.
* Reassess in two weeks.
From 2 citizens (EN1396)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Introduce mandatory quarantine for all international arrivals

In order to slow the spread of covid-19, we need to act proactively. Numbers soar globally, even with many countries, incudluding the US, failing to test their population adequately. The time is now to act to curb the spread, reduce the need and intensity for future lock downs and ease the burden on the healthcase system.
We therefore ask the House to intoruduce mandatory quarantine for all new arrivals, along with other mitigating strategies such as closing, universities and potentially more.
From 2 citizens (EN1398)
COVID-19: Schools
Immediate Suspension of Education Institutions

As the government has implemented a ban on all gatherings of more than 500 people across Australia in response to the exponential spread of COVID-19, it seems illogical that educational institutions gathering hundreds to thousands of students each day from primary schooling to tertiary education would remain active.
We therefore ask the House to enact the immediate suspension of all education institutions within Australia to further prevent the spread of COVID-19.
Australia is still within a position where we can control and minimize the spread of the virus but we must act now.
From 33 citizens (EN1399)
COVID-19: Workplace Relations
Fighting COVID-19 - Businesses to enforce "Work from Home"
Keeping a social distance - 1.5 metres WILL NOT help stopping the transmission and it is not practical in an enclosed office.

1. COVID-19, as per WHO, is a "GOBAL EPIDEMIC" and its risk level is VERY HIGH globally. Cutting off social contact by avoiding non-critical human mobility and crowd gathering is crucial. If a business has the capabilities to allow staff to perform their work duties at home, it has to be enforced;

2. Commuting to work means some staff need to take public transportations, the more and frequent exposures they have, the higher the chance they could be contracted; besides, not everyone can follow a good cough etiquette and hand hygiene. This is not only about personal health and safety, it is about the entire community: if just one of us would become a case, then we would be a walking COVID-19 host, and we would not be willing to put anyone else at risk. Hence, working from home has to be enforced;

3. It would be too late when the confirmed cases and death tolls rocket. As per the Australian Chief Medical Officer, due to the shortage of testing kits, "A new testing regime was being developed to ensure only those most at risk were tested". And if we can reduce the pressure on Australian health system, by taking actions at an early stage, we think we are doing something right.
We therefore ask the House to enforce "Work from Home" for the businesses have the capability.
From 2 citizens (EN1400)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Lockdown Australia temporarily

The spread of Covid-19 is exponentially, almost a fifth of all 368 confirmed cases reported in Australia were recorded on Monday 16/03/2020. The hospital capacity in Australia may not able to cope with the surge if extreme measure not applied. The quicker and extraordinary actions required in an extra ordinary time.

We therefore ask the House to o do all it can to counter measure the spread of Covid-19 in Australia from overseas and domestic by locking down Australia with some exception of basic need and healthcare system for a period of time effectively immediately.
From 11 citizens (EN1401)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Freeze all bills and place country in lockdown
What we are facing is a global pandemic, we must take action now and we must look out for the citizens of Australia to ensure we will not loose our homes and livelihoods during those tough times
We therefore ask the House to freeze all bills and initiate quarantine
From 13 citizens (EN1402)
COVID-19: Higher Education
Cancel outstanding HELP debt to help economy through Coronavirus crisis

For many educated Australian Citizens who don't have the benefit of having their parents fund their education, HELP debt is a significant financial burden. Even for those citizens living and working overseas temporarily, like myself, the debt still needs to be paid. In this time of economic crisis and uncertainty caused by the Coronavirus, the federal government should be doing all that it can to stimulate the real economy and reduce the burden on its citizens to prevent risk of recession and possibly a depression. Clearing all outstanding HELP debt would ensure those that are still employed are able to spend more to keep critical businesses and services going in this time of crisis. This would ensure that a generation of young people have a chance to keep their dreams alive after all those years of study to continue to work hard, have a go and support businesses who employ everyday Australians. According to the latest ATO figures from 2018-19, there are 3 million Australians with HELP debt at a total of $67 Billion, that's $22.3k per person with a HELP debt that would be released back into the real economy over these Australians' lifetimes. Young Australians will carry the burden of continuing to support the economy during this tough time and for many years to come, and should be given the help they need to be able to do this.
We therefore ask the House to clear all outstanding HELP debt.
From 12 citizens (EN1403)
COVID-19: Economy
Save Australia's venues from collapse

The Federal Government has banned all gatherings over 100 people and is likely to restrict this number further. This has already led to major cancellations of events and bookings at venues across the country and puts tens of thousands of Australian jobs at risk. It threatens to bankrupt huge numbers of restaurants, cafes, bars, pubs, theatres, music venues and clubs across our communities.

The Federal Government must step in to provide financial support for venues. Inaction will see hundreds of venues close on our local high streets and in our communities. Canberra has already provided financial assistance for other industries and must act to protect venues from collapse.
We therefore ask the House to:
- Work with local councils to suspend Business Rates on venues for at least 3 months
- Make a financial provision for all staff including casual staff, and self-employed people who cannot work (for at least 3 months)
- Extend Tax Relief to the hospitality, culture and recreational sector for at least the next 3 months
- Support Landlords to allow them to give rent holidays to businesses for at least 3 months

- Create a fund to facilitate financial support for businesses if forced to close / or ensure government forces insurances to cover closures with an additional clause for all businesses including events and festivals
From 12 citizens (EN1405)
COVID-19: Child Care
Fully subsidised child care during the COVID-19 pandemic crisis

Asking the House to enforce the immediate waiving of out-of-pocket daily fees charged by providers of Early Childhood Education, Kindergarten and Child Care services in the environment of the COVID-19 pandemic crisis for parents that choose to take the precautionary measure of keeping their children home
Requesting that the House keep these services functional for children whose parents cannot stop work during this crisis
Requesting that the House continue to pay CCS fees to providers so that they may cover payroll and overhead costs
We therefore ask the House to take action immediately in order to support parents who choose to keep their children out of childcare during the COVID-19 pandemic
From 2 citizens (EN1413)
COVID-19: Economy
Provide a financial stimulus to the Australian Events Industry
The Australian Events Industry, a sector that generates $23 billion, is facing financial ruin.

The Federal Government's ban of indoor gatherings of 100+ people from 18 March 2020 has thrust the Australian Events Industry on the front line of economic fallout. The ban is expected to last at least six months.
Already, the impact on the Events Industry is devastating.
The number of conferences, festivals, meetings and events that occur across Australia every day has effectively gone to zero.

The outlook for professionals, suppliers and talent in the Events Industry is grim. Their income stream has all but ceased, with little to no prospect of income for many months, nor any possibility of alternate employment in the meantime.
The Events Industry were the first and hardest hit, as companies cancelled events as early as January 2020, citing COVID-19 as the reason.
Further, given the considerable time and effort required to arrange festivals, meetings, conferences and events at scale, this industry may be one of the last sectors to enter a recovery phase.

The Events Industry sits at the very centre of the government's ban. While the tourism, hospitality and airline sectors are supported, to date there has been no relief announced for the Events Industry per se.
We therefore ask the House to release a substantial and immediate financial stimulus to the Events Industry.
From 10,188 citizens (EN1414)
COVID-19: United States of America
Deny visitors from the U.S entering Australia

Most of recently confirmed coronavirus cases as widely reported are related to the US. The federal government should consider closing its border completely to the US and broader European countries. Mandatory temperature checks at airports need to be enforced, for both domestic and international travels. With the situation in the U.S getting worse by day, the government should deny entries from the US just like China as a priority before this gets too late.
We therefore ask the House to deny entries from the U.S as soon as possible.
Enforce mandatory temperature checks at airports for inbound and outbound domestic and international travels.
From 7 citizens (EN1415)
COVID-19: Trade and Tourism
Federal Aid Package for Travel Industry

To The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, we are facing unprecedented behaviour changes in our global economy. Travel cancellations, bans and now, airlines grounding of their international fleets into Australia have an unfathomable impact to the people working across this industry.

The Covid-19 virus means that our businesses are unable to survive and due to enforced isolation timeframes, businesses are facing bankruptcy, with the losses guaranteed to intensify as delays remain in place. Without stimulus release from the Australian Government, we will continue down this trajectory, with no relief in sight for many Australians and their families who rely on their income. We understand our industry must make this sacrifice to save people's lives, and that limiting the spread of the virus we help to mitigate the catastrophic impacts to the health of our nation.
Our families understand this cost of sacrifice, yet we are facing an ever-growing list of catastrophes as a direct result.

The economic fallout from this collapse can potentially spearhead the Australian economy into recession. The Travel industry represents yearly revenues in excess of $40 billion, contributing 3% of Australia's GDP, employing over 1 million staff.
We therefore ask the House to release an economic stimulus package to support the businesses survival and ensure adequate recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.
We implore the House to take immediate action to protect the industry from irreconcilable remuneration, the lives of our collective employees and the limit the impact to the economy from recession.
From 1,040 citizens (EN1416)
COMMITTEES
Human Rights Committee
Report

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (11:54): On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights, I present the following reports: Human rights scrutiny report: Report 4 of 2020, incorporating a dissenting report, and Human rights scrutiny report of COVID-19 legislation: Report 5 of 2020.
Reports made parliamentary papers in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr PERRETT: by leave—I am pleased to present the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights' fourth and fifth scrutiny reports of 2020, which were tabled out of session on 9 and 29 April 2020 respectively. These reports contain a technical examination of legislation with Australia's obligations under international human rights law.

Report 4 of 2020 contains the committee's consideration of 14 bills introduced into the parliament between 24 February to 5 March 2020, and legislative instruments registered on the Federal Register of Legislation between 6 February and 4 March 2020. It contains the committee's concluding comments in relation to 13 bills and four instruments. Regrettably, half of the committee, comprising all members from the Australian Labor Party and the Greens, issued dissenting comments to the committee's conclusions regarding the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Amendment (Ensuring Integrity No. 2) Bill 2019. The dissenting members concluded a number of measures in the bill are likely to be incompatible with the right to freedom of association. I encourage my fellow members, the government and others to examine the full report, including the dissenting comments.

The committee's scrutiny report 5 of 2020 is dedicated to an examination of legislation made in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This includes consideration of COVID-19 related bills tabled in the parliament between 23 March and 8 April 2020, and legislative instruments registered on the Federal Register of Legislation between 21 January and 21 April 2020.

In this scrutiny report, the committee provides an overview of Australia's international human rights obligations in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, with a particular focus on the operation of the Biosecurity Act 2015. The committee has found that legislation developed in response to the pandemic is likely to promote and protect the rights to life and health, noting that the right to life requires Australia to take positive measures to protect life and the right to health requires Australia to take steps to prevent, treat and control epidemic diseases. However, the committee has also noted that many of the steps taken in response to the pandemic may also engage and limit a number of other human rights, including the right to privacy, freedom of movement, liberty, and equality and non-discrimination. These rights may be permissibly limited, where limitations pursue a legitimate objective—keeping people alive—and are rationally connected to that objective, and are proportionate. Further information is required to assess this in relation to 17 legislative instruments and one bill, as set out in this report. I encourage my fellow members, the government and others to examine this important report closely.

The role of the Parliamentary Human Rights Committee during this unprecedented crisis is even more important than usual. When governments all around the world are restricting the freedoms of their citizens, including the Australian government, it is crucial that laws designed to restrict those freedoms are thoroughly scrutinised in a bipartisan manner. It is also important that when these restrictions are no longer necessary—hopefully—the freedoms and human rights of Australians are returned, and that any tardiness in so returning is called out.

The committee will continue to regularly report on all legislation, both COVID-19 related and other legislation, during these challenging times. With these comments, I commend the committee's Report 4 of 2020 and Report 5 of 2020 to the House.

Dr WEBSTER (Mallee) (11:58): by leave—Today I rise to speak on scrutiny reports 4 and 5 of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights 2020. It is a privilege to be a member of this committee and to contribute to ensuring that all bills and legislative instruments passed by this parliament are consistent with Australia's commitment to human rights. This work is especially important at the current time, given the nation's fight against coronavirus which has resulted in the most comprehensive restriction of liberties that many of us have ever experienced. For many weeks now, Australians have had their movements constrained, businesses have closed or gone into hibernation and five million people have stopped working. The toll has been great, with the necessary separation of family and friends. The challenges posed by the coronavirus have clearly demonstrated circumstances where the limitation of certain human rights, such as the curtailing of our freedoms, is not only acceptable but a moral and legal imperative. It has shown that in certain situations some human rights need to take precedence over others for the benefit of the nation.

For the better part of this year the scales have rightly tipped in favour of public health concerns in an attempt to preserve the right to life and health. This is an extraordinarily difficult balancing act made all the more difficult by the reproductive rate of this pandemic. I have many people in Mallee who have expressed their gratitude for the exemplary leadership shown by this government—particularly the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Health—and the leaders of state and territory governments as well as the chief and deputy medical officers for their swift action in responding to this unprecedented crisis. I also want to acknowledge our brave healthcare and aged-care workers and all other essential frontline service personnel who continue to risk their health and wellbeing to keep us safe.

The reports introduced today contain the committee's consideration of a number of bills and legislative instruments introduced to parliament this year. Report 4 of 2020 considers 14 bills introduced into the parliament between 24 February and 5 March and legislative instruments registered on the Federal Register of Legislation between 6 February and 4 March. It contains the committee's concluding comments in relation to 13 bills and four instruments, including the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2019 and the Fair Work (Registered Organisations) Amendment (Ensuring Integrity No. 2) Bill 2019.

Report 5 of 2020 is dedicated to an examination of legislation made in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, which I will focus on today. This report includes consideration of COVID-19 related bills tabled in parliament between 23 March and 8 April and the legislative instruments listed on the Federal Register of Legislation between 21 January and 21 April. A number of the measures considered in Report 5 of 2020 have taken under powers set out in the Biosecurity Act 2015. This act is the primary means for the Australian government to manage the risk of diseases entering Australia and causing harm to human health. The act can grant the Minister for Health extraordinary powers if a human biosecurity emergency exists. Such an emergency was declared in Australia in relation to COVID-19 on 18 March 2020. By virtue of their implementation we can already see how these measures present unique considerations for this parliament and the human rights committee. Many of the measures introduced through the Biosecurity Act 2015 and through parliament engage with human rights in significant ways. Such limitations may be permissible if they are shown to pursue a legitimate objective, are rationally connected to that objective and are proportionate in achieving that objective. The limitations imposed by a number of measures considered by the committee are by-products of the intent to promote and protect the right to life and health for individuals residing in this country.

The preservation of life is clearly a legitimate objective, but questions remain as to the necessity and proportionality of the measures seeking to achieve this aim.
