p.span: (c) As at 5 March 2020, approximately 6,260 of the 7,391 clients detailed in the previous table still had permanent residency. Section 501 of the Migration Act 1958 (the Character Test) is the only ground under which a permanent resident who is onshore may have their visa cancelled for character related issues.

The Government has introduced changes to the Character Test through the Migration Amendment (Strengthening the Character Test) Bill which would strengthen a decision maker's ability to cancel or refuse a visa, including permanent visas, based on character concerns. This would result in an increase of character related visa cancellations. To date, the bill has not been supported by the Opposition.
CuDECO
(Question No. 323)
Mr Katter asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 04 March 2020:

(1) Is the Minister aware that CuDeco Rocklands in Cloncurry has gone into voluntary administration, leaving local small businesses and employees significantly out of pocket, and that employees were not paid for months before going into administration.(2) Is the Minister aware there were also reports made to the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC), in the months before going into administration, of questionable business practices—hundreds of staff members are owed wages, small businesses have unpaid invoices, and 6,000 shareholders have lost their investments (many have lost their retirement funds meaning they will now need the aged pension).(3) Will the Government increase the powers of the Fair Work Ombudsman to force companies to pay staff even when in administration. (4) Will the Government increase the powers of ASIC to allow them to investigate illegal activities when reported and act on them to enforce the law. (5) When will the Government put a stop to foreign companies coming to Australia and taking advantage of our people and small businesses.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) I am aware, through media reports and through the honourable member's representations, of some of the circumstances surrounding the voluntary administration of CuDeco Limited. I am also aware that CuDeco Limited was placed into liquidation on 30 April 2020.
(2) See my response to question (1). I also refer you to the Treasurer, who has portfolio responsibility for the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC).

(3) When a business is in voluntary administration (before it goes into bankruptcy or liquidation) the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO) can provide advice and guidance to employees with unpaid entitlements. However, the ability of the FWO to take legal action over unpaid entitlements is limited once a business enters administration.

In 2019, the Prime Minister asked me, in my capacity as Minister for Industrial Relations, to take a fresh look at the industrial relations system. The Government is examining the system to identify how it is operating and where there are impediments to shared gains for both employers and employees, with a view to strengthening the economy and jobs growth, increasing wages and protecting employees' rights. As part of this consultation process, the Government is issuing discussion papers on various topics to ascertain stakeholders' views and identify specific opportunities for improvement.

The consultation process has been paused due to disruptions caused by the COVID‑19 pandemic, although my department is continuing to accept submissions made on the discussion papers released this year. This includes a paper, titled Improving protections of employees' wages and entitlements: further strengthening the civil compliance and enforcement framework, whichwas released on 18 February 2020 and seeks views on the use of the FWO's compliance and enforcement tools.
I will take your feedback about the FWO's powers into consideration as part of this consultation process.
(4) I refer you to the Treasurer, who has portfolio responsibility for ASIC.
(5) I refer you to the Treasurer, who has portfolio responsibility for ASIC.
